Award.AwardTitle: Geometry and Analysis on Nonholonomic structures on manifolds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS 1406193, Principal Investigator: Igor Zelenko

Structures of nonholonomic nature such as bracket generating distributions and sub-Riemannian structures appear naturally in Control Theory with applications to Robotics (car-like robots), Mechanics (ball bearing structures) and the models of visual perception. Distributions are also basic objects in the geometric theory of differential equations and in geometry of real submanifolds of complex spaces (Cauchy-Riemann geometry). The knowledge of invariants of a geometric structure up to diffeomorphisms of the ambient manifolds or, informally speaking, of the quantities which are independent of local coordinate representations of such structures often gives the essential information about various qualitative properties of the geometric structures. In the last decade we developed the novel variational approach for the unified construction of the differential invariants for a very wide class of geometric structures. This approach takes its origin in Optimal Control Theory and Symplectic Geometry. It extends significantly the set of the nonholonomic structures for which the canonical frames and differential invariants can be constructed explicitly and uniformly compared with all previously existing approaches (including the classical Cartan method of equivalence and the Tanaka theory from 1970). The aim of the project is to use these invariants in order to solve a number of natural problems that were not considered in such generality before. The results of this project will bring new geometric tools for Control Theory and Mathematical Physics by providing efficient and uniform algorithms for computing state-feedback and gauge invariants and explicit geometric optimality conditions for extremals of the corresponding variational problems. We will develop a special MAPLE based software package for computation of our invariants and apply the theory to the qualitative study of control and mechanical systems of practical interest.

The main new point of the aforementioned variational approach is that the study of geometry of nonholonomic structures on manifold can be reduced to a simpler (extrinsic) geometry of curves in flag varieties. In terms of these curves we obtain a new discrete basic invariant of the original structure, called the flag symbol and we have an explicit algorithm for construction of the canonical frame for our original structure that depends only on first fixing this discrete information. However, the main properties of these frames and of the invariants they produce are far of being understood. Among the problems that will be addressed in the project are (1) explicit description of the group of symmetries of the most symmetric models with given flag symbol; (2) exploring when the obtained canonical frames are Cartan connections; (3) distinguishing the fundamental set of invariants among all invariants produced by these frames. To reach these goals we will use various tools and techniques from Representation Theory, Algebraic Geometry, and cohomological theory of Lie algebras. Another main theme of the project is comparison theorems in sub-Riemannian geometry. Several essential differences here compared with the Riemannian case form serious obstacles in obtaining sharp analogs of the classical Rauch and Bonnet-Myers comparison theorems. To overcome these obstacles we propose to work on the infinitesimal version of comparison theorems, i.e. given a sub-Riemannian metric to describe directions in the tangent space at this metric to the space of all sub-Riemannian metrics in which consecutive conjugate points along the corresponding extremals become closer. We also shall study natural flows on the space of sub-Riemannian metrics along which the infinitesimal comparison theorem holds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the award period we made a significant progress in the following four direction: local geometry and symmetries of nonholonomic distributions with given flag symbol,  local geometry of uniformly Levi degenerate Cauchy-Riemann (CR) structures, sub-Riemannian geometry, and generalized inverse Wronski problem.

Regarding  the first part of the project we first unified the notion of the flag symbol and the construction of the canonical frames for distribution of odd and even rank. This unification became possible after extending the theory of canonical frames of curves in generalized flag varieties from a special class of curves to the general one. Secondly,we essentially advanced in answering one of the main questions of the project: What are  the algebra  of infinitesimal symmetries of the maximally symmetric distributions with a given Jacobi symbol? As a highlight of this theory we obtained the first example of distributions  with the following remarkable properties: the dimension of their algebra of infinitesimal symmetries has an exponential growth w.r.t. the dimension of the ambient manifolds (in fact, the dimension of these algebras behave as the sequence of Fibonacci numbers) and the highest order of the weighted jet by  which symmetries are determined is quadratic with respect to the dimension of ambient manifold (note that previously the highest  known growth of symmetry algebra was quadratic and the highest known order of weighted jet determinacy was linear with respect the dimension of ambient manifold, as in the case of parabolic geometries).  These results will form a core for the  monograph in preparation (jointly with B. Doubrov) which will make a bridge between the classical methods in the equivalence problem (such as the prolongation of G-structures), the Tanaka prolongation procedure, and our variational approach.

Regarding the second part of the project, while the local geometry of Levi nondegenerate CR structures of hypersurface type is very well understood thanks to classical works of  Chern-Moser  and Tanaka, the equivalence problem for uniformly Levi degenerated, satisfying additional nondegenericity assumption, was solved in 2013  in the smallest dimensional case of 2-nondegenerate 5-dimensional structures only. The classical Tanaka approach does not detect the k-nondegenericity. Exploiting a natural bigrading hidden in such structures we developed a bigraded analog of Tanaka theory for construction of canonical absolute parallelism for 2-nondegenerate hypersurface-type CR structures in arbitrary (odd) dimension with Levi kernel of arbitrary admissible dimension.The developed formalism significantly systematizes the equivalence problem for Levi degenerate CR structures of arbitrary degree of nondegenericity and opens up new perspectives for its solution in a very general setting.

Regarding the third part of the project, we got results in two directions:  The first direction is devoted to measure contraction properties of sub-Riemannian metrics, which leads us to the first general sub-Riemannian analog of the classical Bonnet-Myers compactness theorem  and of the Liouville theorem for sub-Riemannian harmonic functions.The second direction is related to the question whether one can recover uniquely, up to a constant factor, the sub-Riemannian metric from the knowledge of its geodesics, considered as unparameterized curves. This problem is motivated by a widely accepted opinion in Neuroscience that human movements follow a decision that undergoes an optimality criterion. There is a natural class of sub-Riemannian metrics called generalized Levi-Civita metrics (extending the classical class of Riemannian metrics) for which such recovery up to a constant factor is impossible. These metrics  are very special, because the geodesic flow of such metrics admits special integrals and certain separation of variables occurs. We conjectured that the generalized Levi metrics are the only unrecoverable metrics. Our main achievement is  the proof  of a weaker version of this conjecture that unrecovarable up to a conformal factor metrics admit special integrals for their geodesic flows and a separation of variable occurs on the level of nilpotent approximation. As a consequence, we obtained that all sub-Riemannian metrics on distributions with generic nilpotent approximations are recoverable up to a conformal factor.

Regarding the part of the project on the generalized Wrionski map (which are linear projections of Grassmannians with kernels that  do not meet the Grassmannian), the main question is whether the linear projections coming from a Lagrangian involution are the only linear projections of degree greater than 1. We proved this in the following cases: when the degree of the linear projection is exactly equal to 2 and in the case of Grassmannian of 2-planes in 4 dimensional space and 3-planes in 6 dimensional space. The results of this part have direct applications to System and Control theory,namely for the description of all linear control systems such that for a generic configuration among all configurations of poles that can be realized by a static output feedback there is another static feedback that realizes the same configuration.

During the project 1 PhD student and 4 Master students graduated and 4 PhD students continue under my supervision.
